awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Mapping the Human-Technology Frontier to Improve Trauma Care: A Transdisciplinary Approach to Identify Opportunities, Challenges, and Risks
awd_abstract_narration:
Trauma-related injuries are the leading cause of death in Americans under the age of 45. While human costs are overwhelming, the economic costs are also alarming. In 2005, fatal unintentional injuries resulted in $1.3 billion in medical costs and $82.9 billion in lost work costs, including cost of goods and services not produced and provided by the individual for the duration of their working life. Furthermore, diagnostic errors and delays in treatment are the most common errors reported in trauma resuscitations, accounting for almost 75% of preventable deaths. Using a conservative estimate of $10,000 per error-related adverse event, the cost estimate is $418 million annually. The trauma workforce is sizable: In 2017 there were 42,348 practicing emergency medicine physicians, and, in 2019, an estimated 167,375 practicing emergency medicine nurses, 78 percent of which are women. Unfortunately, however, 38 percent of the nurses and approximately 60 percent of the physicians in emergency medicine reported some symptoms of burnout. This project will draw from a broad range of expertise and perspectives in emergency medicine, sociology, communication studies, interior design, computer and information science and engineering, and industrial and systems engineering to investigate the clinical practice of trauma care. 

This planning grant will develop transdisciplinary and convergent research capacity, research infrastructure, and foundational work to build a comprehensive research agenda for supporting and improving patient safety and prevent burnout syndrome in trauma care. The goal is to design clinically informed intelligent technological interventions for optimal decision-making in trauma care and to facilitate effective team training for diagnostic and treatment processes in trauma resuscitations. The primary research objectives are two-fold. First, researchers will develop a holistic conceptual framework for, and a theoretical understanding of, diagnostic and treatment care planning to model and analyze trauma care. Second, the project will develop an evidence-based approach for challenge, opportunity, and risk assessment to evaluate and justify pervasive technological interventions for trauma care. The research team will conduct a series of observations, interviews, focus group studies, and organize charrette workshops to collect data. Researchers will also use content analysis, mapping analysis, statistical methods and machine learning to analyze and mine data, and utilize grounded theory to guide the identification, modeling, and analysis of the salient features of the underlying human-techno-physical system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant (2026518) was awarded an interdisciplinary research team that is comprised of experts in industrial and systems engineering, computer science, sociology, interior design, and emergency medicine at the University of Florida. Research activities centered around three areas: (i) To develop a holistic conceptual framework for, and a theoretical understanding of, diagnostic and treatment care planning to model and analyze trauma care; (ii) to develop identify opportunities, challenges, and risks associated with the development and use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) applications and systems for trauma care; and (iii) to identify a convergent research agenda that is grounded in the diagnostic and treatment care planning framework for trauma care and guided by the perceived and real challenges, opportunities, and risks.

To develop a holistic conceptual framework for, and a theoretical understanding of, diagnostic and treatment care planning in trauma resuscitation care, the systems engineers conducted one-on-one cognitive interviews with EM physicians. The findings from this activity led to the development of detailed process flowcharts of ABCDE (Airway Breathing Circulation Disability Exposure) primary survey. These flowcharts are more comprehensive and detailed than the flowcharts that are included in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) Student Course Manual, the main textbook used for the training of EM residents in the field. Furthermore, these process flowcharts focus primarily on the cognitive (e.g., information processing and decision making) processes of the EM physician who serves as the team lead and oversees the interdisciplinary healthcare team that delivers the trauma resuscitation care, and, hence, capture and reveal how EM physicians “think” during trauma resuscitations.

Next, to develop a comprehensive approach for opportunities, challenges, and risks associated with the development and use of AI applications and systems for trauma resuscitation care, the systems engineers worked with researchers in social sciences and computer science to design and conduct an interview study. The research team conducted semi-structured, one-on-one interviews with EM physicians and EM nurses who are trauma care certified. The findings from this activity not only confirmed some of the well-known challenges, opportunities, and risks associated with the use of AI applications and systems in medicine in general, but also revealed some aspects that are specific to trauma resuscitation care. In general, AI’s three capabilities that relate to (i) processing large amounts of data quickly, (ii) recognizing patterns in large data sets, and (iii) making predictions emerge as its major strengths that can help improve trauma resuscitation care in several ways at the bed side while taking care of the patient, in the office for examining hospital-based data, and in the classroom for helping train EM residents and fellows more effectively. For instance, while an AI application can predict timeline based on a series of vital signs over time and alert the team that the patient may experience an unexpected life-critical event (e.g., hypotension or cardiac arrest), an AI system with access to entire hospital database can provide immediate access to a patient’s care history and alert the team about some critical information that may be missed that could change the course of treatment (e.g., allergies or blood clotting problems). Similarly, an AI system may assist an EM physician to search and analyze cases to identify effective interventions under certain circumstances to help improve patient care in general. Finally, AI-enabled training systems can identify weaknesses of residents and personalize their training simulations to ensure that they gain the experience and develop the competencies they need. Hence, numerous research opportunities exist for supporting a trauma team during resuscitation and the training of EM residents to that end. Challenges expressed relate to the development, maintenance, and effective use of AI applications and tools. In addition to the well-known and broadly discussed infrastructure-based (such as cybersecurity concerns and protecting private patient information) and development-based (such as the use of data sets that represent a hospital’s patient demographics), and implementation-based risks associated with AI application systems, some implementation-based risks were expressed such as a concern for training next generation EM physicians and nurses who rely on AI applications and systems too much and not being able to perform effectively when such systems are not available or how a collaborative partnership between an AI system and an EM physician should be structured.

Finally, using the findings from the interview study, the systems engineers continued to work with social science researchers to design a survey study to explore the perspectives of EM physicians about the future impact of AI in EM in general and trauma resuscitation care in particular. The survey tool is aimed to investigate the perceptions related to the impact of AI on EM physicians; the impact of AI applications on the quality of trauma resuscitation care; EM physicians’ personal plans to engage with AI; and the process of AI integration. Currently, this survey tool is being prepared for nationwide distribution.
